newsitem.title: FRANCE: France urges Turkish pull-out from Iraq, restraint.
newsitem.headline: France urges Turkish pull-out from Iraq, restraint.

text.p: France voiced concern on Friday over a reported buildup of foreign troops near the Iraqi border and urged Turkey to withdraw its forces from northern Iraq where they are pursuing Kurdish separatists.

"France wants to express its acute concern. It calls upon Iraq's neighbours to stick to utmost restraint in order to avoid worsening a fragile regional situation," Foreign Ministry spokesman Jacques Rummelhardt told a news briefing.
"It calls for the earliest withdrawal of Turkish troops from northern Iraq," he added.

Turkey's state-run Anatolian news agency has said that Syria, Iraq and Iran have built up their forces near the borders of a Kurdish enclave in northern Iraq where Turkish troops are fighting Kurdish rebels.

It said the buildup was believed to be part of an effort by the three countries to provide shelter within their borders to Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) rebels fleeing the Turkish air and ground assault.
Turkish troops pushed deep into northern Iraq and dug in on Thursday, the ninth day of a drive against Kurdish guerrillas. Baghdad dismissed the mission as a pointless pursuit of "ghosts".
Iraqi Kurdish officials said Turkish troops had pushed 200 km (125 miles) into Iraq, much further than past incursions.
